'''Jimmy Burns''' (born February 27, 1943, [[Dublin, Mississippi|Dublin]], [[Mississippi]], [[United States]]) is an award winning [[United States|American]] [[soul blues]] and [[electric blues]] [[guitarist]], [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p201468/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Jimmy Burns |author=Ankeny, Jason |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=March 13, 2010}}</ref> Although he was born in the [[Mississippi Delta]], Burns has spent nearly all his life in [[Chicago]]. His elder brother, [[Eddie "Guitar" Burns]], is a [[Detroit blues]] musician.<ref name="Encyc"/>

==Biography==
Burns's father was a [[sharecropping|sharecropper]] who performed as a singer in [[medicine show]]s.<ref name="Encyc">{{cite web |url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G2-3431000013.html|title=Eddie "Guitar" Burns |author=Manheim, James M. |publisher=Encyclopedia.com |accessdate=March 13, 2010}}</ref> At the age of 12, Jimmy Burns moved with his family to [[Chicago]] and four years later joined The Medallionaires who recorded a couple of [[doo-wop]] tracks.  Recording mostly solo in the 1960s, Burns issued [[single (music)|singles]] for the USA, [[Minit Records|Minit]], Tip Top and Erica [[record label|labels]].<ref name="Burns"/> He toured the [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]] with his backing group, the Fantastic Epics, and with another outfit called Jimmy Burns and the Gas Company into the early 1970s.  Burn's 1972 single, "I Really Love You" was named in the top 500 singles of [[Northern soul]] in 2000,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rocklistmusic.co.uk/steveparker/northern_soul_top_500.htm|title=Northern Soul Top 500|last1=Parker|first1=Steve|date= |website=rocklistmusic.co.uk |publisher=Julian White|accessdate=August 30, 2013}}</ref> and it is sought by collectors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popsike.com/JIMMY-BURNS-I-Really-Love-You-RARE-NORTHERN-SOUL-45/190447583639.html|title=Jimmy Burns I Really Love You Rare Northern Soul 45|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|website=Popsike.cm |publisher=Popsike|accessdate=August 30, 2013}}</ref> Burns took a long break from the [[music industry]] after the early 1970s to raise his family.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Burns"/>

He performed infrequently until the early part of the 1990s, when he started a long residency at Chicago's Smokedaddy [[nightclub|Club]]. It was there that [[Delmark Records]] boss [[Bob Koester]] first heard Burns perform, and agreed to record him after hearing only one set of music.  His debut album for [[Delmark]] in 1996, ''Leaving Here Walking'', was produced by Scott Dirks, and was awarded the 'Best Blues Record of the Year' title by the [[American Association of Independent Music|National Association of Independent Record Distributors]], and received two [[Blues Music Award|W.C. Handy Award]] nominations. Burns then began touring internationally.<ref name="Burns"/>

The more recently formed Jimmy Burns Band includes Anthony Palmer (guitar), E.G. McDaniel (bass), and James Carter (drums).<ref name="Burns">{{cite web|url=http://www.jimmyburnsband.com/bio.htm |title=Bio, Jimmy Burns Band |publisher=Jimmyburnsband.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-31}}</ref>

Jimmy Burns played guitar on his brother Eddie's 2002 album ''Snake Eyes''.<ref name="Encyc"/>

Burns's wife, Dorothy, died on February 12, 2010. They had six children.<ref name="Burns"/>

==Discography==
===Albums===
*''Leaving Here Walking'' (1996) - [[Delmark Records|Delmark]] / [[P-Vine Records|P-Vine]]
*''Night Time Again'' (1999) - [[Delmark Records|Delmark]]
*''Back to the Delta'' (2003) - Delmark
*''Live at B.L.U.E.S.'' (2007) - Delmark<ref name="Albums">{{cite web|author=Jimmy Burns |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/jimmy-burns-mn0000851985/discography |title=Jimmy Burns | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1943-02-27 |accessdate=2013-08-31}}</ref><ref name="Wirz"/>
*''Stuck In The Middle'' (2011) - Velrone

===Singles===
*"Forget It" (1964) - USA Records
*"Give Her To Me" (1965) - Tip Top Records
*"You're Gonna Miss Me When I'm Gone" (1966) - Tip Top Records
*"I Don't Need (Your Help)" (1966) - Tip Top Records
*"I Tried" (1967?) - [[Minit Records]]
*"I Really Love You" (1972) - Erica Records
*"Can't Get Over" (1980) - Dispo Records [[Extended play|EP]]<ref name="Wirz">{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/burnsfrm.htm |title=Eddie Burns & Jimmy Burns |publisher=Wirz.de |accessdate=2013-08-31}}</ref>
